member.name: M:MilSym.MilSymbol.MilBrush.GetFill(System.Windows.Media.Brush)
member.summary: Gets the background fill style for the specified brush. There is little or no reason for a user to call this method unless they wish to capture the style for other reasons.

member.name: M:MilSym.MilSymbol.MilBrush.GetLinePresent(System.Windows.Media.Brush)
member.summary: Gets the "Present" linestyle associated with the specified brush, a style for drawing solid lines with a thickness of 10. There is little or no reason for a user to call this method unless they wish to capture the style for other reasons.
member.param: The brush to use for the solid lines, typically a solid black brush
member.returns: The style for drawing solid lines with the specified brush

member.name: M:MilSym.MilSymbol.MilBrush.GetLineFillPresent(System.Windows.Media.Brush)
member.summary: Returns the line, fill, and present Style for the given brush or adds a line, fill, and present style based on the brush. "Present" in this context refers to the object being present (solid) as opposed to anticipated (dashed). In this case, the Style has both a solid line and a solid fill.
member.param: The brush for which to get the Style.
member.returns: The style corresponding to the requested brush.

member.name: M:MilSym.MilSymbol.MilBrush.Add(System.Boolean,System.Windows.Media.Brush)
member.summary: Method to load up the various default line and fill styles
member.param: True if the style includes a fill.

member.returns: Returns the style while also adding it to the list of default styles.

member.summary: Returns the appropriate brush type according to the current color scheme

The particular color scheme property, Dark, Medium, or Light
member.returns: The brush corresponding to the color scheme property

member.name: P:MilSym.MilSymbol.MilBrush.ColorScheme
member.summary: Gets or sets which of the three default color schemes to use: dark, medium, or light. The default is "Light." This is a static property so it is possible for one thread to overwrite the user by a different thread. This behavior may change in the future.

member.name: P:MilSym.MilSymbol.IMilSymbol.LabelStyle

member.name: P:MilSym.MilSymbol.IMilSymbol.LabelString
member.summary: Gets or sets this write-only string property to provide an easy way to set multiple labels at one time. The syntax is "label=value;label=value;..." where '=' and ';' can be any two characters that are ONLY used as separators in the string. It is also possible to use the same character for both '=' and ';' with a subsequent loss of readability.

member.summary: Gets or sets the brush for drawing the background of a symbol, typically dependent on the symbol's standard identity (aka affiliation).

member.name: P:MilSym.MilSymbol.IMilSymbol.OverrideFillBrush
member.summary: The brush used that overrides fill colors of symbols that are always the same color otherwise. Will not affect symbols that change color based on affiliation.

member.name: T:MilSym.MilSymbol.MilSymbol
member.summary: The MilSymbol class is the only class of interest for most developers who wish to plot military symbology. Its various methods support any valid, and some invalid, symbol codes (once fully implemented). Labels can be specified as well as symbol scales and brushes to use for rendering the symbol's frame. Since MilSymbol extends Canvas it can be used anywhere that a Canvas can be used.

member.name: M:MilSym.MilSymbol.SymbolData.IsTopFlat(System.String)
member.summary: When is the top of the symbol flat? Answer: 1. normalize StandardIdentity to 'F', 'H', 'N' or 'U' 2. return true when it is Subsurface 3. return true when it is Neutral 4. return true when it is Friendly Units, Installations, or SOF 5. return true when it is Friendly Emergency Operations a. technically, friendly emergency equipment is not flat
member.param: The symbol code to check for a flat top to the symbol.
member.returns: Returns a boolean to indicate whether the top of the symbol is flat.

member.name: M:MilSym.MilSymbol.SymbolData.GetBounds(System.String)
member.summary: This function returns the symbol bounds for the various standard symbol backgrounds. Tried to do this as a dictionary but the possibilities exploded. The exceptions to these sizes are the symbols that have headquarters or installions built-in. If that built-in is in the normal symbol code place (SymbolCode[10-11]) we're OK. But the designers threw in a few curveballs that we're going to special case for now.
member.param: The symbol code.
member.returns: A Rect reprsenting the bounding rectangle in the same space as the resource dictionary.

member.name: M:MilSym.MilSymbol.SymbolData.GetHqFactor(System.String)
member.summary: Return the headquarter's factor to help position the headquarter's staff
member.param: The symbol code for the headquarters.
member.returns: A fractional offset as a double ranging from 0.0 to 1.0.

member.name: M:MilSym.MilSymbol.SymbolData.IsBaseFlat(System.String)
member.summary: When is the base of the symbol flat? Flat symbols are easier to draw against. Answer: 1. normalize StandardIdentity to 'F', 'H', 'N' or 'U' 2. return true when it is Air or Space 3. return true when it is Neutral 4. return true when it is Friendly Units, Installations, or SOF
member.param: The symbol code.
member.returns: A boolean indicating whether the base of the symbol is flat.

member.name: P:MilSym.MilSymbol.TPG.ISymbol2525CCanvas.Scale
member.summary: Gets or sets the scale with which to render the symbol. The default Scale of 1.0 is rather large (approximately 300x300). In practice a Scale of 0.1 to 0.2 is effective. When symbols are rendered in a browser that supports magnification it is possible to change the zoom factor to see more detail.

member.summary: Gets or sets the rotation angle for the current symbol. The standard severely limits the occasions when rotating a symbol is allowed so this option should be used with caution.

member.name: P:MilSym.MilSymbol.TPG.ISymbol2525CCanvas.SymbolCode
member.summary: Gets or sets the symbol code property for the current military symbol. Valid symbol codes are fully defined by the MIL-STD 2525C specification. As of this writing that specification is the first reference at the Wikipedia link http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_symbology.

member.name: P:MilSym.MilSymbol.TPG.ISymbol2525CCanvas.LabelStyle
member.summary: Gets or sets the label style property for the current military symbol. Currently on the FontFamily, FontSize, FontWeight, and Foreground properties are used.

member.name: P:MilSym.MilSymbol.TPG.ISymbol2525CCanvas.LabelString
member.summary: Gets or sets this write-only string property to provide an easy way to set multiple labels at one time. The syntax is "label=value;label=value;..." where '=' and ';' can be any two characters that are ONLY used as separators in the string. It is also possible to use the same character for both '=' and ';' with a subsequent loss of readability.

member.name: P:MilSym.MilSymbol.TPG.ISymbol2525CCanvas.LineBrush
member.summary: Gets or sets the brush for drawing the outline of a symbol, typically black and either solid or dashed.

member.name: P:MilSym.MilSymbol.TPG.ISymbol2525CCanvas.FillBrush
member.summary: Gets or sets the brush for drawing the background of a symbol, typically dependent on the symbol's standard identity (aka affiliation).

member.name: P:MilSym.MilSymbol.TPG.ISymbol2525CCanvas.OverrideFillBrush
member.summary: The brush used that overrides fill colors of symbols that are always the same color otherwise. Will not affect symbols that change color based on affiliation.
